name: Bonsai
description: Grow your tree, prune it, and watch over it as it matures into adulthood. The tree will become what you train it to be - you are the mastermind behind it's path in life.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: Intel Core-i3 4160 Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 4400 Storage: 200 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 and above Processor: Intel Core-i3 4160 or better Memory: 6 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 660 Storage: 300 MB available space

reviews.review_text: This is my first negative review of any game on stream - that's how disappointed I am.  First, I was looking forward to this game. The discription sounded like something zen and relaxing. So I put it on my wishlist, and, after a while, I bought it. With the first start, I was hit by severe disappointment: I tried hard to like the 'game' as is, but in the end, I would even consider $0.01 to be way too expensive for this snot. The execution is so depressingly lazy and unloving that I could write a better and more realistic 'bonsai game' from scratch in a day with only rudimentary OpenGL knowledge - and in the end this would probably even turn out to be orders of magnitudes less resource hungry than this monstrosity. Honestly, I would be ashamed of myself to bring an abomination like this 'game' to steam let alone even dare to think about taking money for it.   Pros:  (+) Nice Zen like game idea. (+) You can mute the background music ingame.  Cons: (-) 'Game' started with extremely loud music, but settings have no audio controls whatsoever (-) Wasn't able to run it without fullscreen. (-) Can not choose type of tree to start with (-) No tutorial, no background information, nothing - not even credits. (-) Horrendous user interface. Why do you need two buttons which only toggle each other ? Clicked on the 'water' icon while it was already selected, therefore the 'scissord' button was automatically selected, and instead of growing the tree. I cut it at its base irrevocably. (-) Evervating and absolutely unfitting background music you instantly want to deactivate.  (-) Tree only grows while running the game, but game minimizes as soon as you tab outside, so progress can't be seen while doing something else. (-) Trees only grow two-dimensional most of the time and do not grow biological / natural at all. (-) Branches do not tend to split where cut. Branches appear randomly in obscure places (e.g. inside other branches). (-) No way to influence tree growth. Except letting it grow randomly and then cut away what you don't want. (-) Leaves are not attached to branches. All leaves randomly change position every time tree grows or is pruned. (-) Leaves are randomly cluttered all over the branches - if at all - and do not even point in the direction of the tree. (-) Leaves are outlined by a thick line of background colour, rendering underlying leaves and branches invisible. (-) Even when the stem and the branches are twice as thick as the cursor, it is still a pixel hunt to select them. It doesn't help that the leaves are obsfucating everything once they appear. (-) About a thousand things more of what is wrong or lacking with this abomination.

At first I was a bit sceptical about this game even after one of my friends recommended it to me. But I was wrong it turned out to be a great gaming experience and now we have tons of fun all day playing BONZAI and watching our trees grow. You get attached to the trees they are like your children 10/10 buy it now!

Essentially, all you do is click on a tree, click to grow, click to cut. Good time waster when you want something simple to play. Only hard part is patiently yet furiously clicking to get a sapling into a tree.
Step 1 = Start game  Step 2 = Load Game  Step 3 = Enable auto clicker  Game Crashes  10/10 Would Bonsai again.
Senpai noticed me alot more as I played this game. 9/11 would buy.
Bad textures Terrible controls I didn't see a day/night cycle  ... but it's worth the asking price.
